name: Gia
title: Great fun!
review: Everyone loves this.I bought it for my blind kid, who was instantly charmed.She loves the tactile drawing experience, and pushing the balls back down as well.It would be great if it were a little easier to get one ball at a time to raise, especially when using one‚Äôs fingers to check the drawing- often a group of 3 or 4 will raise when placing the stylus on the board.This prevented her from writing her name in braille which would otherwise have been possible and a real bonus for blind kids everywhere to be able to create the picture they are thinking of and sign it!With some practice, she can push down just the balls she wants to leaving the picture or letter she was going for, but it makes for a bit of tedium .The sighted ppl are very happy with it !Overall it was a great purchase , and I will buy more for the rest of the kids in my clan

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on April 21, 2021
name: Kumiko
title: Satisfying nontraditional drawing pad.
review: Originally, I bought this for my autistic son(who very much enjoys the noise and feel to this) but I found myself and my other child playing with it from time-to-time. It's simple and just satisfying.The board is not as small as I thought it would be. Mind you, it's not HUGE but it's a good size to take it on the go and not worry about taking up too much space. Not only that but it seems to be sturdy enough to being dropped a few times on the ground and still be in one piece.The clicking of the metal balls, when using the magnetic pen, is so satisfying. More so, when you poke or drag your fingers across to push the metal balls back down to 'erase' it. And speaking of the pen, I love how when you slide the pen in, to put it up in the slot above the drawing board, there seems to be a magnet inside to snap the pen into place and hold it so it isn't able to slide out so easily.So far it stood up to being thrown, beaten, and used this long and its still in one piece. Not just that but it's still being used here and there instead of completely forgotten, like their other toys.(looking at you Barbie Dollhouse. Sigh...) I would recommend it if you considered something like this.

Not ideal, especially when the other one we have works very well. I do wish the stylus was connected, but I suppose you can't win them all. Very noisy.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 21, 2020

title: Kids love it
review: Kids love it they should have the pen with string attachments so kids won‚Äôt lose the pen

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on December 6, 2020
name: B. Noij
title: One of the little balls does not come out all the way
review: The product arrived with a defect. One of the little metal balls does not come out all the way. I live on a Caribbean island and had the item shipped to me through a freight forwarder. Shipping it back for a warranty return would cost more than the value of the item. So it looks like we're stuck and my 8 year old has a defective present. I hope in some way the seller can contact me (no way for me to contact them) to organize a replacement.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 22, 2020
name: diljs
title: Fun for kids and adults!
review: We have a little one in the family who is constantly moving, exploring and creating. This is one of her favorite new toys, and Dad likes it, too!This is such a clever toy. You use a "pen" with a magnetic tip to attract steel balls to the surface of a grid. As you do so, the bee-bees make a distinct "clack" which reinforces a child's efforts to create. With a 21 x 23 hole grid, you can make a tremendous variety of geometric designs and images.When you are done drawing, you push the steel balls down to start over. This can be hard on your fingers, if you do it with your bare hands. However, it works great to use either the side or the plain tip of the "pen."Measuring 6 x 7.5 x about 3/4 inches, it's the perfect size for traveling. It's also lightweight and portable. The plastic pen stores in a slot of the Magnatab screen. Our daughter can enjoy it in the back seat during a long drive--provided Mom doesn't go crazy from the sound!The price is right, too. For about $10, this makes a great stocking stuffer for Christmas for kids young and old.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 16, 2020
name: Susan G. Good
title: Great Toy for Traveling, but a little loud!
review: I ordered this Magnatab Free Draw for my 2 younger grandkids.They do a lot of traveling with their parents, so I am always looking for ways to amuse them in the car and in planes.This Magnatab would be perfect except for one problem.This toy is small enough to carry easily and use in small spaces.It's great fun to "draw" on the board using the stylus - my granddaughter is very creative and loves to draw with this.It's also lots of fun to watch the little magnetic balls follow the stylus or even a finger.It would definitely be a 5 star toy, except for the fact that those little magnetic balls are really loud when they click together.The parents are fine with this in the car, but it would definitely not be acceptable in an airplane or in a restaurant.Maybe the manufacturer can modify it somehow to reduce the noise, because it's a great concept!

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 10, 2020
name: R. ALLEN
title: Disappointed this experienced teacher (and her children)
review: I was disappointed in this product.I played with it myself before letting my preschool-aged and kindergarten-aged children try it, and found that it was very difficult to make a picture or a shape.When using the stylus, even with careful and steady hand, small metal balls would fall or raise intermittently such that my shape, letter, or simple drawing would be irregular or inconsistent.I tried MANY times.Then I had the children try it - they were intrigued to be able to push and pull the small balls with the stylus and they loved knowing it was magnetic.Their attempts to draw a simple picture or even a simple line were not rewarded though.Areas that they did not touch with the stylus intermittently dropped just as they did when I tried it.Younger children were not frustrated - they just continued to watch the lines change with the stylus - but those who wanted a LETTER or a SHAPE were disappointed.I‚Äôve definitely seen other similar boards that work much better.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 3, 2020
name: DebraS
title: Fun toy
review: My daughters have had hours of fun with this Magnatab.It is small enough to take for traveling too.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on November 2, 2020
name: Michael
title: Fun toy, but needs improving
review: This is a fun toy, that out of the box works well - the magnetic pen "pulls" these metal ball upwards so that you can create images from these dots. However, after a large number of uses, we found that the "dots" no longer stay tightly held and fall down after being pulled upwards by the pen, so that you cant make the image that you wanted to. They need a slightly tighter fit in the shafts for each dot or slightly larger dots.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 31, 2020
name: tiffanylynn
title: Kind of fun
review: My tween-age daughter requested this to use as kind of a fidget so admittedly, she isn't part of the normal target audience for this toy. The tablet seems very durable which makes it a great option for young kids or something to keep in the car that might end up getting tossed around a bit. The pen is full size and stores nicely at the top of the device. The metal balls come up easily when you run the pen over the holes and click satisfyingly into place. The magnet is pretty strong and sometimes draws balls into holes next to the one you are intending, but you can push them back down fairly easily (some seem a little more difficult than others).I will say, this toy is pretty loud - not so much when "drawing" but clicking all the balls down to clear the slate makes a decent amount of noise. It doesn't bother me but would be something to keep in mind if you were hoping to use in a public setting (school, airplane, restaurant, etc).

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on October 30, 2020
name: Olivia
title: The Magnatab Free Draw isn‚Äôt as good as the other versions.
review: The media could not be loaded.¬†This review is for the Magnatab Free Draw and who it is best suited for.My experience with Magnatab in the past, has been the larger ABC‚Äôs version, which I loved in my classroom. The Free Draw version is small (6x7), which you would think would be good for travel, but it is too loud to take out to a restaurant or on an airplane. I also find it too small to draw much of anything. It is fine for basic shapes, writing 1 or 2 letters at a time, then erase and try again. We even tried tic-tac-toe without much success. It was very hard to fit the X‚ÄòS and O‚Äôs and have them legible.I have added a video to show you how basic shapes work for an adult. In the pictures, that is a Christmas tree.If you keep it simple, it may be perfect for you. It‚Äôs great for fine motor skills. Many children fear making a mistake when writing the alphabet. This is great because you can simply erase that mistake away.I prefer the larger versions of Magnatab, but this may be perfect for your use.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2020
name: Cassandra
title: Best travel ever!
review: We do a lot of traveling with our 6 children including long international flights.Over the years we have tried many different toys and activities to keep the kids happy. This is by far their favorite. It kept all of them entertained for hours from my 11 year old down to my 2 year old.I also have some children who do not consider themselves to be very creative, yet they found confidence in the simplicity of being able to create really unique patterns.I also like the fine motor control practice they are gaining while using it.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2020
name: Chelsey Nixon
title: No complaints
review: This is much smaller than our alphabet magnatab, which makes it the perfect size for travel. I stick it in our stroller and then hand it to the toddler every day before a walk and it always keeps her entertained. It was initially hard to get the beads to go down but after the first few times it worked better. The stylus stays in place well. Honestly no complaints.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2020
name: John T. Horner
title: Slightly smaller than I imagined, but good for young children
review: This item is exactly as described so my perception of the size was personal and says nothing about the description that's that even though it was a little smaller than I expected it turns out to be the perfect size for the young children it is designed for much bigger and it could be too heavy for little hands. Great fun to play with, very neat, and easy to store.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2020
name: AB
title: too small to have any detail
review: We have several of these toys.The letter and number boards are much better than this one.It is smaller. It's really not large enough to make a picture with any detail.The images or shapes aren't very easy to see.It is appealing to click the balls into place and push them back down but overall, I don't care for this version of the magnatab.¬†

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2020
name: NicbachDVM
title: Great, creative toy that inspires tactile learning
review: We have a few of these and our kids love them (3 and 8). They inspire creative play and help improve tactile response. It makes an annoying clicking noise, so caution if you're sensitive to noise. It's easy to carry and portable, which is great for car rides, etc. Great, creative toy.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2020
name: Jeffrey Van Wagoner
title: Entertained a 2 year old
review: Our almost 2-year-old granddaughter was occupied with this toy for over 15 minutes.That's impressive!It is very fun to see the metal balls come up and they stay up very well.It's fairly easy to 'erase' them by running the stylus sideways over them.This is great for small motor skills for young kids.You can create pictures and even create letters.Overall, this is a great toy for kids and adults like it too.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2020
name: M. Garrison
title: Not kid friendly at all
review: This has been pretty much a bust, which is disappointing given how much my kiddo has loved other Magnatab toys. Unlike the letter/number sets we have, the little metal balls on this one have to be pushed down really firmly to go back in -- enough so that even as an adult I have to push hard enough for it to be uncomfortable, and my kiddo can't get some of them down at all. How hard it is varies by row, which makes me think maybe it's a manufacturing thing? On top of that, the contrast isn't great, and so whatever pattern you make isn't actually that noticeable. This is the first time my child has ever asked where the goodwill bag is, 10 minutes in with a new toy.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2020
name: Jakob
title: Pretty disappointing honestly
review: I remember this toy from when I was pretty young, I liked playing around with it, practicing letters and generally try to draw low-resolution images (house, sun etc)I figured getting it to my kids will be just as fun for them, I did not take into account that there are better products that allows you to do just that without the downsides of this toy,The toy is aimed to 3+ ages, it could possibly be for even younger as the build quality is good, it does what it supposed to and there are no toxic or small parts to be hazardous to your kids,The biggest issue that hinders the fun of this toy is the fact that the magnet is so strong you cannot "draw" in a single stroke, more often then once your child will get stuck while drawing a straight line (or circle or whatever) and have the "pen" stuck in a hole/to a magnet and ruin the fluidity and fun of simply drawing,All in all I hoped for something fun for the kids but it is currently collecting dust and not being an option for my little ones as a potential game even if they are offered to play with it.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2020
name: Lehigh History Student
title: Great size for travel
review: My preschooler has loved Magntab products since she discovered them at school. She loves the freedom to be creative that this version provides and I love the smaller scale. It‚Äôs a great size for travel, but the distinctive click of the beads can be irritating until you get used to it. The sensory feedback and imaginative play balance add to the benefits of this product.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2020
name: mofo83
title: Great toy overall... but loud!
review: The MagnaTab Free Draw is one of those toys that is very simple but has a bit of "magic" to it. It's very neat and satisfying to see the little ball-bearings "jump" up and stick in place as you doodle, and then drop back down as you draw your finger or stylus across them. Compared to a MagnaDoodle, it's definitely more "mesmerizing" for my kids. They'll sit there for extended periods of time and really focus as they click those little balls into place.I'll also mention that it seems sturdy and well-made, and is very easy to use for just about anyone.That said, it's not perfect. For one, it's pretty difficult to draw anything with too much detail - you'll be making more rough representations or designs than you will detailed art/drawings (or, maybe we're just not good at it!) But the biggest downside is that this toy is loud ‚Äì and I'm talking LOUD! Most art toys are great in that they keep kids quiet while engaged, but not this one. The balls click pretty loudly when they "jump up," and they're especially loud when being erased with the stylus (and of course, kids will use this as a maraca whenever they can...) Seriously, don't underestimate how loud this thing is - and I haven't even used it in the cramped quarters of a car yet!I'll also note that the price seems a little high to me, as this toy is relatively small and simple. It is well made, though, so maybe $15 seems about right?Overall though, if this is the sort of thing your kid (or the kid you're gifting it to) enjoys, this is a pretty great and unique toy. Just don't expect peace and quiet!

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on February 18, 2021
name: Amazon Customer
title: Over time, less satisfying
review: Arrived in perfect condition, worked just like on the YouTube video and my kid loved it.Lost stars because with use, the magnetic balls no longer securely stay in the holes, so you don't get that satisfying click when you push them back in, they even loosely fall back in if you shake it.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2020
name: D3 & T
title: Fun simple toy
review: Bought this for Christmas just as a extra keep busy item. Was surprised how much attention it got the first few days. The pen went missing pretty quick, but that was due to everyone playing with it. The metal balls did require a little extra pressure the first time but after that worked great.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 9, 2020
name: Zeke Lark
title: Fun Play Toy - Not For "Drawing"
review: This is a fun toy for a toddler.The idea is good, but the little "spheres" that make the picture aren't small enough to do any "real" drawing, the drawings end up looking like a small piece of a single-colored picture out of a really old video game (if they're recognizable at all).That being said, if your child just wants something to practice fine-motor skills, holding a pen, etc. this is a fun toy (and it's surprisingly addicting to just "draw" the little spheres up and push them down again.Note that this one is about 3/4 the size of the "glow in the dark" free draw version of this.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on September 2, 2020
name: Brad B.
title: Super fun, I think I like it as much as my toddler does!
review: Any toy that doesn't take batteries or make noise immediately has my attention. I'm a big believer in tactile toys and toys to improve eye-hand coordination. This toy checks all the check boxes. Since each "pixel" is a metal ball, the toy has a bit of heft to it, but they used nice, thick plastic for the toy's construction. This thick plastic keeps the toy from flexing at all and unless you run it over with a car, there won't be any breaking. The screws on the back are safety screws so that older, enterprising kids don't get any wise ideas. The pen locks onto each ball quickly and strongly and as it pulls it to the top of the little barrel it sits in, it stays there. Every now and then you need to lock on to a ball twice in order to get it well seated, but it's no big deal. For me, the bigger entertainment is pushing the balls back down once you're done drawing. There's something satisfying about pushing each ball down one-by-one (kind of like popping bubble wrap). This is a great car toy as well, and this will definitely be a mainstay.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 31, 2020
name: Betty
title: Another magnetic winner
review: This is another doodle box to foster creativity that keeps all the parts contain ed. There is nothing g to spill and is also fun in the car. It is also engaging for adults.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 28, 2020
name: J.Prather
title: Excellent toy!
review: This is a fantastic toy for creative and sensory play.Using the stylus, kids draw up the magnetic balls into the holes in order to create pictures, letters or numbers.I like the smaller size of this one, and the convenient holder for the stylus.It can click in place, hopefully cutting down on the chances of losing it!Kids love the click sound when the balls come into place, and also love running their hands over the balls to "erase" the screen.This reminds me a bit of the classic etch a sketch toy in it's creative capabilities but adds sensory elements that make this toy a good investment for years to come.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 25, 2020
name: A Regular Joe
title: A little imagination and a lot of time passes in the car
review: Our kids love these little free draw magnetic tabs. There's something about using each little ball one at a time to create a picture that captivates the imagination and keeps them working on it for hours in the car at a time. Planes, planets, spaceships, trees, they love to show off their creations. I also like that it doesn't erase as easily as an etch-a-sketch so fewer tears. Recommended.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 23, 2020
name: LT
title: Great toy for any kid!
review: The media could not be loaded.¬†The Magnatab Free Draw is a fun toy that my 5 year old and 2.5 year old enjoy playing with! The Magnatab comes ready to play with straight out of the box and includes the red Magnatab and gray stylus. To draw on the tab you move the stylus along the grid which pulls the magnetic balls to the surface. To erase on the Magnatab you can use your finger or lay the stylus horizontally to push down erasing the balls. The designs you draw on the Magnatab are more boxy not curved due to the grid format. I like that this toy is self contained so it's easy to travel with or play with in the car. My favorite aspects of this toy is that it teaches creativity, fine motor, and science concepts through the use of magnets. Every child I've seen interact with this toy has been immediately drawn in and thoroughly enjoys playing with it!

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 23, 2020
name: Amanda D
title: Not as fun as other versions
review: Surprisingly, this was not as much fun as the write-assisting versions of Magnatab. Although this one allows you to draw whatever you want, there is almost too many beads too close together. Sometimes the metal balls want to slot in themselves (without the pen) and sometimes they refuse to stay put (with the pen). Sometimes you have to have the ball meet the pen in which case, there is a tougher magnetic pull and the pen doesn't flow as naturally as in the other versions. The board is smaller than I expected, so you're sort of limited on what to "draw" and because of this, the toy does not hold focus as long as the other Magnatab puzzles.However, there are still so many features which make it a four star review for me. First, it has a very calming "feel" to it. It reminds me of a pin-art board in terms of how it feels on your hand. Of course, these are balls and not pins, so it is both safer and a little more relaxing and welcoming. Second, the sound the balls make when they click into place is very euphonious, and the sound when they are not in their slot reminds me of a rainmaker. This is a great "time-out" toy for kids; they can calm down while still using their imaginations through hands-on play. I also think the ingenuity of the toy makes it interesting to kids. My children (7, 5 and 2) are drawn to this toy, especially when they have to have calm/quiet time.

review_data: Reviewed in the United States üá∫üá∏ on August 19, 2020
name: Garrett Zecker
title: Excellent analog non-screen-time edutainment fun!
review: The Magnatab FreeDraw is an excellent toy that allows a screen-free edutainment option for my kids. Honestly, I wasn't sure what I was getting when I ordered it, but it is a plastic and steel-ball-bearing and magnet grid-based toy that can be used for drawing, spelling, and just free-entertainment play. Essentially, it is a big binary pixel system of drawing, where great imagination and innovation can be had in the backseat of a car ‚Äì from tic-tac-toe to guess the picture to practice with letters and numbers. In the images I shared, I am showing my 6 and 11-year-old‚Äôs interpretation of Spongebob, the Harry Potter icon, and a free-drawn masterpiece. It is like those magnetic whiteboards with the iron filings from the nineties, but since the device is so binary with the ball bearing being either activated or deactivated, there will never be any screen burn, the pieces will never tire or get worn out, and since the kids can return the styl8us back to the device, it will never get lost.Overall, a great little toy that can be used educationally, recreationally, and interpersonally. Perfect for the living room, the back seat, or the classroom!
